c.)+U\sum\limits_{i}(n_{i\uparrow}-\tfrac{1}{2})(n_{i\downarrow}-\tfrac{1}{2})," display="block"><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>J</mi><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mo>†</mo></msubsup><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>.</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>U</mi><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↑</mo><mi/></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↓</mo><mi/></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\end{subequations}
where $G_X$ has a direct relation to the local charge susceptibility \cite{Florens2002}. The model can be solved exactly when the spin-degeneracy $N$ and the number of rotor flavors $M$ is increased from $N=2$ and $M=1$ to infinity, keeping the ratio $\mathcal{N}=N/M$ fixed \cite{Florens2002},  and this limit provides a qualitatively correct description of the metal-insulator transition. (Below we fix the parameter $\mathcal{N}= 3$, for which the DMFT phase-diagram is quantitatively reproduced \cite{Florens2002}.) The derivation of the resulting integral equations for $G_X$ and $G_f$ in real time is a straightforward reformulation of the original work \cite{Florens2002} on the Keldysh contour, and we just state the final result:  The Green's functions \eqref{GFX} satisfy Dyson equations

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle G_{f}(t,t^{\prime})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
for some fixed time $s_0$.  (For a Lorentzian peak, $\tau$ is the inverse width).
 The time $\tau_\text{ne}$ first increases with $t$ and then decreases, tracking the evolution of $\tau_\text{eq}(T)$ a function of temperature (Fig.~\ref{fig:Gf_derGf}b). 
 We then find that the maximum of $\tau_{\rm ne}(t)$ as a function of time ($\tau_\text{max}$) coincides with the crossover scale $\tau_*$ (dashed lines in Fig.~\ref{fig:Bandwidth}d), and moreover, this value is reached at a time $t_\text{max}$ proportional to $\tau_*$ (Fig.~\ref{fig:Gf_derGf}c). This demonstrates that the long lifetime of the spinor provides a bottleneck time for he relaxation in the crossover regime. 

\begin{figure}[tbp]
\centerline{ \includegraphics[width=0.99\columnwidth]{./figure03.eps}}
 \caption{
a) Retarded spinon Green's function $G_f^\text{ret}(t,t-s)$ as a function of relative time $s$ for 
various different times $t$ ($U=4$, $\beta=10$, $\lambda=0.5$), and in equilibrium (dashed line). 
The slope decreases for $t\lesssim 32$ and increases for $t \gtrsim 32$.
b) Inverse of the slope
[Eq.~\eqref{tau}] 
as a function of $t$ for $\lambda=0.5$,  $\beta=10$, $s_0=16$ and various values $U$ below the metal-insulator transition.
c) Crossover time $t_\text{max}$ plotted against $\tau_\text{max}$, where $(t_\text{max},\tau_\text{max})$ 
corresponds to the maximum of the curves $\tau_{\rm ne}(t)$ in panel b). }
\label{fig:Gf_derGf}
\end{figure}


Although properties of $A_f(\omega)$ are not simply reflected in the equilibrium single-particle properties, one can approximately express the timescale $\tau_*$ in terms of the electronic degrees of freedom. The width of a sharp resonance in $A_f(\omega)$ is given by the imaginary part of the self-energy $\Sigma_f$, which depends on $G_X$ and $\Delta$. In the crossover regime, we can, to a first approximation, relate the rotor $G_X$ to the electronic Green's function by  $A(\omega) = \frac{1}{2} A_{X}''(\omega) \coth(\beta\omega/2)$, by setting $A_f(\omega)=\delta(\omega)$ in the convolution $G_{loc}(t,t')=iG_{f}(t,t')G_{X}(t,t')$
\cite{footnote02}.  Analytic continuation of $\Sigma_{f}(t,t')=i\Delta(t,t') G_{X}(t',t)$ then gives
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\tau_{\text{ne}}^{-1}(t)=-\partial_{s}G_{f}^{\rm ret}(t,t-s)/G_{f}^{\rm ret}(t%
,t-s)|_{s=s_{0}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>τ</mi><mtext>ne</mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>ret</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>/</mo><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>ret</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\tau^{-1}_{\rm eq}(T)=-\Sigma_{f}^{\prime\prime}(\omega=0)\approx-\int d\omega%
\,\frac{\Delta^{\prime\prime}(\omega)A(\omega)}{\cosh(\omega/2T)^{2}}," display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>τ</mi><mi>eq</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>′′</mi></msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mo>-</mo><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>ω</mi></mpadded><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>′′</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>cosh</mi><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>
